Guilherme Costa

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/9621931150328983
  • Última atualização do currículo em 03/07/2014

Possui graduação em Medicina pela Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (1991). Residencia medica em cirurgia geral no Hospital das Clinicas da Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (1992-1996). Participou do Grupo de Transplante de Figado do Hospital das Clinicas da Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (1994-1996). Especializacao em cirurgia de transplantes na Universidade Louis Pasteur de Estrasburgo, Franca (1997). Fellowship de pesquisa (1988-1999) e fellowship clinico-cirurgico (1999-2001) em cirurgia de transplantes no Instituto de Transplantes Thomas E. Starzl da Universidade de Pittsburgh. Residencia medica em cirurgia geral no Centro Medico da Universidade de Pittsburgh (2001-2004). Desde 2004 atua como Professor Assistante no Centro de Reabilitacao Intestinal e Transplante, Divisao de Cirurgia de Transplantes, Departamento de Cirurgia, Universidade de Pittsburgh. A principal area de interesse e a de transplante de orgaos abdominais (figado, rim, pancreas, intestino e multivisceral), com enfase em transplante intestinal e multivisceral. No campo de transplante intestinal e multivisceral, as areas de estudo sao: imunosupressao e imunotolerancia, reabilitacao nutricional na falencia intestinal e evolucoes tecnicas das cirurgias do doador e receptor. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - Atual
Long term renal outcomes post intestinal and multivisceral transplant
Descrição: Intestinal transplantation is a life-saving treatment offered to patients with irreversible intestinal failure who can no longer be safely maintained on parenteral nutrition. The procedure was pioneered in Pittsburgh, and in the 25 years since the first successful intestinal transplant, recipients can now expect 5-year survival in excess of 70%. There is however a significant rate of renal dysfunction in intestinal transplant recipients: over 20% develop CKD, 10% require renal replacement therapy and in general there is up to 70% decline in eGFR at 2 years. Renal dysfunction in this population is likely to be multifactorial, with contributions from chronic dehydration, sepsis, calcineurin inhibitors, and oxalosis. Pre-, peri-, and post-transplant variables associated with long term renal dysfunction has not been closely examined. Further, unlike liver transplantation, there is no consensus as to when to include a kidney as part of the primary graft. The aim of this study is to retrospectively examine all patients who have undergone intestinal/multivisceral transplantation at UPMC between 2000-2012 in order to identify variables that are associated with poor renal outcomes and the need for renal replacement therapy. The medical records will be examined, and clinical variables analysed such as pre-transplant risk factors for CKD, pre-transplant renal function tests, operative details, episodes of allograft rejection, medications prescribed, immunosuppressive drug levels and longitudinal measures of eGFR. .
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Guilherme Costa - Coordenador / BOND, G. - Integrante / SINDHI, RAKESH - Integrante / CRUZ, RUY J. - Integrante / HUMAR, ABHINAV - Integrante / MAZARIEGOS, GEORGE V. - Integrante / SOGAWA, HIROSHI - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Cell Function and Transplant Outcomes
Descrição: We are conducting a research study to help us understand why some people undergoing a transplant have better outcomes with regard to transplant rejection or anti-rejection medicines. We are especially interested in understanding whether rejection and the need for anti-rejection medicines can be predicted with blood tests. These tests measure the behavior of different types of white blood cells that are known to cause rejection. The specific types of white blood cells that will be evaluated are T-lymphocytes, B-lymphocytes and monocytes. The specific behavior of these cells that will be studied includes how these cells sense (antigen presentation) or attack (inflammation) transplanted organs. Inflammation will be studied by measuring a protein called CD40 ligand inside these cells. Lymphocyte apoptosis for rejection risk assessment, and antigen specific CD154 producing lymphocyte subsets for monitoring infection will also be studied..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (2) / Especialização: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Guilherme Costa - Integrante / George Mazariegos - Coordenador / Kyle Soltys - Integrante / Rakesh Sindhi - Integrante / BOND, G. - Integrante / Rkesh Goyal - Integrante / Feras Alissa - Integrante / Chetan Ashokkumar - Integrante / Amanda Brown - Integrante / Ira Fox - Integrante / Jeffrey Rudolph - Integrante / Rachel Sda - Integrante / Robert Squires - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Intestinal Transplantation for End-Stage Crohn's Disease
Descrição: Intestinal transplantation has recently evolved and has been more frequently utilized to rescue patients with irreversible intestinal failure who no longer can be maintained on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) therapy. End-stage Crohn s disease has been the second leading indication for intestinal and multivisceral transplantation in the adult population. The aim of this study is to address the procedure s therapeutic efficacy and the impact of disease recurrence on long-term outcome. This study will include all adult Crohn s disease patients who received an intestinal or multivisceral transplantation at the Intestinal Rehabilitation and Transplantation Center, Thomas E. Starzl Transplantation Institute, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center between May 2, 1990 and June 30, 2012. The UPMC medical records and the database of the Intestinal Rehabilitation and Transplantation Center database using an honest broker will be reviewed for pertinent information with emphasis on diagnosis, gender, parenteral nutrition, surgical history, pathology, type of transplant, immunosuppression, rejection, disease recurrence, graft loss, and survival..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Guilherme Costa - Coordenador / BOND, G. - Integrante / SOLTYS, KYLE - Integrante / SINDHI, RAKESH - Integrante / CRUZ, RUY J. - Integrante / HUMAR, ABHINAV - Integrante / MAZARIEGOS, GEORGE - Integrante / SOGAWA, HIROSHI - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Risk of Small Intestine Transplantation in Patients with Significant Hepatic Fibrosis
Descrição: Small intestinal transplantation has evolved over the past two decades from what was considered an experimental procedure to what is considered today as the only long-term option for patients with intestinal failure. The recipients of small bowel transplants have irreversible complications associated with the chronic use of total parenteral nutrition. Intestinal transplantation has shown remarkable advancement not only in volume of transplants performed but also in outcomes, due to advancement of organ preservation, surgical technique, immunosuppression, and postoperative management.Intestinal transplantation is unique because of the complex immunologic events which follow transplantation of a lymphoid organ. Although the liver has a protective effect on transplantation, because of the liver organ shortage, isolated small intestine or liver-free multivisceral transplantation were performed. This study examines the long-term outcome of these patients..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (0) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Guilherme Costa - Coordenador / Bond, Geoffrey J - Integrante / SOLTYS, KYLE - Integrante / SINDHI, RAKESH - Integrante / CRUZ, RUY J. - Integrante / HUMAR, ABHINAV - Integrante / MAZARIEGOS, GEORGE V. - Integrante / SOGAWA, HIROSHI - Integrante.
